text: Now the tape is on, so everything is on. I will tell you to be honest from the start that I don't feel real suited to do this interview. I really like your work. I've read everything. I've read some of it more than once. I'm a real left hemisphere person and so some of the things that you write I feel instead of I don't see the logic, but I feel it. And so sometimes I'm going to be grabbing for words because I just don't know how to express myself very well. I'm better on tapers than a loud. Well we edit this heavily and try to make everybody sound as good as possible. It's very informal. If you want us to repeat a question or you don't like something you said or something we said we'll just go back and do it over with so there's no problem. And if you got to take a break or you just get tired or whatever just let me know. So let's start it. Okay your background is in English and apparently you went quite far in your education in English and then teaching and now you're a writer and you write science fiction. How did you decide or why as a person so interested in English do you write in the genre of science fiction? Well the truth is that I have wanted to be a writer since I was in about the eighth grade and I did not necessarily want to be a science fiction writer. I wanted to be just a writer. The reason that I am doing science fiction now or have done primarily science fiction is that I was first successful in submitting stories that had a fantastic or a science fictional element and in having them sell the other stories, the mainstream stories that I wrote received primarily rejection slips early on and as I said before I'm kind of like the rat in the experimental cage who goes to the lever and presses it and when the food comes out of one particular lever that's the one he goes back to and continues to press and that's the way I have done as far as science fiction goes to some extent. It's not that I don't care for science fiction and I'm doing it solely because it was profitable or more profitable than the other type of writing but simply that I ended up finding very receptive editors in this particular field and that accounts for it more or less. Does science fiction give you perhaps a range it's very forgiving as far as the subject matter and the way it's handled a little more so than other genres. Is that attractive to you? Certainly I think that's true. I think that science fiction does permit a writer to deal with just about anything that he or she wishes to deal with. You can handle contemporary events by projecting them into the future. You can speculate about the past. You can speculate about the distant, distant future. You can speculate about origins and ultimate ends so that I think that really science fiction is a tremendously flexible genre and that's one of its main attractions to me and one of the reasons why I think I continue to write it even though I have aspirations to do other things and have done other things. Do you write for a particular audience or do you write what pleases you and it by happy chance does seem to tickle a lot of people? I think that for the most part I try to write what interests me and I hope then that it will interest somebody else. I've read a number of things fairly recently which suggest that even though my work is very well crafted and carefully thought out that I may be not reaching the audience that some other writers are reaching because their work seems more readily accessible on a first look I wish that that were not the case but I don't know how to do things any differently than I do them. I try not to be inaccessible, that's for certain and I do feel that some of my more recent work has reached a larger audience than perhaps the first two or three novels that I wrote. Okay now we'll start into the line of questions kind of about specific works and the one I want to start with is for the Eyes of Fire which was your first novel and that came out in 1975 and that's the first thing I read of yours because I read a very good review of it right when it came out and it got award nominations but then four years later or so you came out with Eyes of Fire and you said that if you had had your way, the text and the title of the other one would vanish from the earth, what made you think that the first one was so bad? Well it's not that I thought that the first one was so bad and incidentally it's not that I wanted to get rid of the title, I still like the title of Funeral for the Eyes of Fire much better than I like, Simply Eyes of Fire but my editor at Pocket Books when I rewrote the book felt that we ought to give it a title that was new but that at the same time reflected the fact that it was not a brand new work that I was revising in earlier work. As far as my feelings about a funeral for the Eyes of Fire go the original novel published by Valentine, I just feel that I was learning my way then, that was the first time I had ever attempted anything at novel length, I had done short stories and novelas up to that point but never anything of the length or the substance of funeral and to me when I go back and read the book now I can see all of the places where I was obviously a beginning writer struggling to create a narrative and very often lapsing into many essays of one sort or another rather than having the action proceed in a logical and really orderly fashion because of the behavior of the characters. As a consequence when I go back and look at it I see my characters lecturing each other I see gaps in the narrative, I see not inconsistencies necessarily but I just see the awkwardness of a young writer trying to handle a form with which he's not yet familiar. I honestly feel that in the revision which Pocket Books and my editor there and I called Eyes of Fire I honestly feel that there are those things are smoothed out. I also feel that some of the thematic material is more carefully integrated into the narrative than it was the first time around and that I had thought a little bit more thoroughly about that thematic material and that's one of the reasons that I prefer Eyes of Fire of the revision that it took original although I wish that I could have kept the original title. This book has something in common with some of the other books in that it's to some extent an anthropological study of these primitive aliens why it's got encounters between the shaman and technology that sort of thing the aliens were treating very shabbily. Is this kind of a parable of some things that have happened in our past? Well I'm sure that it's a parable of some of the things that have happened in our past and that continue to happen in our relationships to primitive people today and I probably should put primitive in quotes because that's a term that is frowned upon in the anthropological circles right now but at any rate I do think that it was a kind of dramatic framing of situations that have taken place in the confrontation between advanced civilizations and supposedly primitive in quotes of civilizations and it seems to me that projecting it into what, setting on a distant planet that I was just kind of presuming that this was the sort of thing that could happen over and over again but at the same time really it was a comment on the conflict between two different approaches of viewing the world one rather the technological approach and one rather mystical or what do you call it the left brain side I guess. Yeah I like that well that's the right brain but that's I'm unfortunately I'm the other one so that's the next novel then chronologically speaking is I had to wait until a paperback came out called beneath the shattered moons why title change I'm sure that may not have been your choice I'll look up the original title Well the original title of the poem of Paul McLeese called Andrew Marvel itself is a kind of answer to by Andrew Marvel entitled to this poem of these poems and deals with what long experiences of time and mankind's fragility and smallness in comparison to these long spans of time at any rate in and strange decadent treat I was drawing a show that civilizations do rise and fall and the line from Gleesha's poem seems to be to be for Paul when the book was sold to a paperback publisher however Donald Wolheim and Dahl books he did not feel that that was the sort of title that was going to be in K-Marts and bus stations and shoe shine shops to pick up a copy of the paperback but it needed a little more commercial title he gave me the chance to choose various titles and I think I made a list of the four or five shattered moons was one of them which really kind of echoes early title by at Christ Burroughs under the moons of Mars so I felt that that was fairly commercial sounding and it still didn't disturb me too much replacing it for the other although I do prefer the other title which many people regard as pretentious Okay, let's explore similar to here between in strange decadent treaties and the short story or the long short story or whatever it is the white otters of childhood which is by far my favorite story and to these you have the Parfax and these people that banish mankind to some kind of island and there are some similarities but one is in the 52nd century one is in the 120th century so I was going to ask stories come from the same kind of known universe Yes, it's difficult for me to talk about this with a great deal of authority right now because it's been so long since I thought about either one of them at the time though I did intend for and strange that act pretend the trees pardon me to be a kind of far future sequel to the white otters of childhood in other words the situation in and pretend the tree arises after the colonizing of a planet in another solar system out of the situation that prevailed on earth as it's set forth in the story the white otters of childhood it's difficult for me at this point really to explain what I was going to attempt to do with those things I do know that I considered on the street of the serpents the white otters of childhood and strange that act pretend the trees is a kind of trilogy a thematic trilogy if not necessarily a trilogy in which all of the characters are related to that sort of thing Okay, kind of the same question here the stories blooded on a rank in the House of Compassionate Shareers seem to share the same universe with stolen faces and transfigurations is this another known universe, thread of a known universe that's kind of woven through your work I think you're probably referring in particular to the fact that the aliens from one story may crop up in another the aliens from one novel may crop up in a short story and I also used the term galactic com I think to describe the galactic authority which is colonizing the galaxy for us yeah this was kind of the shorthand that I used at the time in order to keep from having to invent a complete colonizing authority in each story and also because I liked some of the alien creatures that I had come up with I didn't feel that I wanted to discard them completely so I would use them again if possible but it wasn't really a it wasn't terribly systematic that's one thing I could say about it I wasn't planning to set dozens and dozens of novels against this background and dozens and dozens of stories okay the two books, The Little Knowledge and Catacombs I want to look at them together for just a minute Catacombs is a fusion or what I call a fusion of six previously written stories in a new one right yeah six old stories in a new one and then A Little Knowledge was an original novel how did those early short stories evolve did they evolve it were you thinking of a series and then you or did you just say hey I confused these together and make something kind of nice out of it well the first story that I ever wrote in that series was the one called if a flower could eclipse and I wrote that without thinking that I was ever going to do another story against the same background and that of course is the urban nucleus of Atlanta the dome city of Atlanta not a terribly original idea of the dome city but when I wrote that story it was only the second story that I had published and I was thinking that a future city should be a dome city and I was trying to write science fiction of the sword even though that particular story has a strong fantasy element as well after I wrote that however I I guess I realized that there were possibilities for other stories and I wrote another one and that one was the windows in Dante's hotel which appeared in orbit 13 I believe orbit I can't remember at this point really one of the orbit volumes edited by Damon Knight and at that point I guess having written the second story I realized that I could go on and write others against the same backdrop with some of the same characters recurring and that was what I ended up doing really it wasn't a conscious plan from the beginning by any means in fact I had to do a little bit of rewriting when I went back in order to make these stories connected in a sensible way you mentioned that this was the dome city of Atlanta and that dome cities aren't that original in science fiction but I sense when I read it that a literal dome city wasn't your first priority that a dome city gives the writer a chance to talk about things oh Atlanta was isolated and it was kind of withdrawn and if I remember right the rest of the cities and the world weren't domed and they were out among the stars whereas Atlanta was just kind of all isolated and I wanted to ask you in that vein why Atlanta what why did you choose Atlanta well I should mention that I did have it set up so that there were other cities on the North American continent that were domed in fact this was called the Federation of Urban Nuclear so I think that there were supposed to be approximately 20-25 cities and they would have included New York, Chicago, Los Angeles all of the major cities on the North American continent all of the major cities of the United States I guess you could say so that there was a network of dome cities the idea here however was just as you say kind of metaphorical each one of the cities was its own universe, its own world that people were withdrawn and isolated and they practiced the kind of isolationism in fact in the story the windows in Dante's Hell the old woman Amelia Longhope who is bound by two people who were going to her apartment really to discover what's happened to her they find that she has created an entire world in her apartment which resembles the bridge of a starship as from an old television program and that she has been looking outward while her own society has been looking inward so that was one of the things that I was trying to do with the dome city I wasn't interested in the dome city as a technological marvel so much as I was I guess I was looking at each city as a kind of petri dish and I was trying to see what the human beings the bacteria whatever you want to call it inside that petri dish were going to do how they were going to behave and why they were behaving in the ways that they did so it was one way of focusing in on the human condition in a in an unusual way and in a metaphorical way the aliens from 61 Cigny were as I think aliens would probably be which is inscrutable but you wrote about them so the question I'm really curious about they were looking for salvation were they were they really looking for salvation were they sincere I pause because I really don't know what to tell you at this point I would say that what I wanted to happen in that story was I wanted to examine and here I'm really going to have to stop and think because it's been a while I wanted to examine what would be the likely consequences of the conversion of an alien species to a human fate what would be the consequences to the aliens and what would be the consequences in particular to the human being and I guess my reason for wanting to do that is that I've always been interested in theological matters in one way or another and this seemed to me certainly a rather extreme theological speculation but certainly one that has a degree of validity especially if you believe as I have a tendency to believe that there is other life in the universe that we are not the only sentient creatures around and that we are not the only sentient creatures around who are going to wonder about their origins their ultimate ends what have you yeah I would say that the the aliens were probably really genuinely looking for a variety of salvation at the same time they may have been trying to show that they were despite all of their inscrutable behavior companions to the human beings who had taken them in that there is a kind of brotherhood across what the sea is face okay the novel Stolen Faces this is one of those that I had trouble kind of reformulating a question about because it hit me more emotionally than it did logically but it's more or less a leper colony and again it's got this theme of an exiled group that's exiled because they have this disease and it's got some characters that are really hurting that sort of thing one of the questions I wanted to ask you about that was which I want to talk about some other things later is the Spanish influence did your experiences in Spain have anything to do with this story or did it come from something else there were several influences on that particular story and I would say that the Spanish influence the fact that I attended my last year of high school in Spain and an American dependent school outside of Seville did have an influence partly because the one foreign language that I have is Spanish that's the one foreign language that I can deal with with any degree of authority and also that helped the other two influences on that particular book however were a book I can't remember the author's name at this point but it was a study of the Aztec civilization and Aztec culture and at the same time another book about Father Damien who was the leper priest on Malachi an island in the Hawaiian group and so my disease muformacy as I call it in that particular novel stolen faces is a variety of leprosy I say as much in the course of the novel itself except that it can affect somebody even in a temperate climate or a cold climate as well as a tropical climate which is where Hanson's disease or leprosy usually strikes the whole point of the book really though was to examine the nature of prejudice and also what prejudice itself does to those who are discriminated against and really that's the point of inspiration for stolen faces Transfigurations was the next novel and it was a continuation of death and designation among the Asahdi I figured it was in the same universe as stolen faces and to me the Asahdi were really alien which again I think real aliens would be and this was an anthropology study and it was also as I said a continuation of the death and designation did you just that story you liked the background that's worth thinking did you always have the idea of completing it and making a novel out of it No, I never always had the idea I think when I wrote that story back in 72 or 73 that I felt that I was pretty much finished with it that it was complete by the time I actually undertook to do transfigurations I had thought some more about the characters in that story both the humans and the aliens and I had also done a great deal of reading on human origins a lot of which I worked into the novel that followed that one No Enemy But Time but at the same time I guess I was really kind of laying the groundwork for No Enemy But Time with the research that I did that carried me through transfigurations the reason that I probably expanded transfigurations or death and designation among the Asadi into a full length novel that I called transfigurations is that by that time I was a full time writer I knew that this was one of my most popular stories that there had been questions about it some of the Luthians had not been tied up and I wanted to deal with the material again and I wanted to deal with it from from the perspective of my new knowledge about human origins and primate ethology that sort of thing so that was one of the reasons that I went ahead used the original novella as part of the text and created a good deal of more information about new characters and a sequel to the original novella in the course of the novel This is one of those real obvious questions but I have to ask it because I do want to know the answer too In transfigurations the aliens eyes are very important of course a funeral for the eyes of fire or eyes of fire just the title that goes without saying that they are and also the house of compassionate shares and pinion fall the eyes are really important so it seems to me that you have kind of not a fixation but they obviously symbolize something is that true? Well I would say that the eyes certainly do symbolize something I don't know whether I want to go a whole lot further than that I guess that it has always seemed to me that the eyes are what's the old cliche the windows of the soul and for an alien species I think they would be similarly a means of looking into the heart of the creature who has those eyes I think too I was looking early on when I wrote the early story pinion fall which was my first story I was looking for a way of making my aliens seem alien and one of the ways was to describe them physically and one of the most outstanding characteristics of any creature I think are the eyes and how they differ from one species to another so the aliens in pinion fall had eyes like insects in a funeral for the eyes of fire I guess I was again looking for a means, an exotic means of establishing the fact that my aliens were truly alien and by giving them different eyes, eyes like gems that was one way of doing that there may have been some subliminal influence too from one of the novels of Ursula Le Guin I'm trying to think now which was a city of illusions I think one of her characters has very very strange eyes but Ursula Le Guin has been an influence on me from way back and maybe that came into it to some extent too as far as the eyes of the Asadi go and the fact that they are a means of communication as well as a means of seeing and also a means of feeding when you discover that they enabled these creatures to photosynthesize part of their food I think there I was looking at the eyes in a functional sense as well as in a symbolic sense as if they really were a physical component of their make up that could help them survive Knowing them in but time is also an anthropology book as you said you probably on this one had to do a lot of homework I would think for the prehumans Yes I've told people that I probably did three and a half to four years of research for that book and I believe that that's true and by that I don't mean that I was continuously researching and doing nothing else not writing anything else but only researching but I nevertheless did spend a great great deal of time reading material to make my proto humans my hominids in that book as near to the real thing as I could imagine so I read people like Lewis B Leakey and Mary Leakey and Richard Leakey the entire Leakey clan, Donald Johansson everything I could get my hands on and scientific journals and news magazines that related to new discoveries in East Africa, Tanzania, Kenya wherever they happened to be Ethiopia when Donald Johansson came along so yes I spent an awful lot of time researching the physical nature, the stature the possible lifestyles of these hominids but also the flora and fauna at the same period so that I could make a credible stab at what kinds of other animals they would encounter what kind of vegetation they would be living among, how they would have to go about their survival strategies in other words so yes that took me a lot of time. I found it very very enjoyable while I was doing and I really kind of put it out of my mind since then I imagine that I may come back to it later on but I have kind of set it aside since then. That book I personally viewed is kind of a two-ponged oh it had two facets okay that engage me. One was the anthropology the lore and that sort of thing, that was fascinating but I also really liked the protagonist. He was really engaging, likeable and in science fiction you, especially modern science fiction, you don't often find that but I really like the guy. So I would assume that he just popped in your mind or does the character just form gradually and that's just how he turned out eventually. I will have to say that really he formed gradually over the composition of the book. There were a number of things that my plot dictated. I had to have a character who was somehow attuned to the distant past and particularly the distant past of Pleistocene East Africa and as a consequence I came up with a character who had vivid dreams even from his infancy on about this particular period so that his attunement to the Pleistocene in East Africa would make it possible later on for an Air Force time program to actually send him back bodily to that period or a simulacrum of that period as I explained it in the book so that much I knew I was going to have to give him. After that however I was really kind of on my own to come up with the sort of person that he happened to be and that unfolded for me gradually in the composition of the book and I was kind of surprised to discover who Joshua Campa really was or the kind of character that he really was and that was one of the nice things about writing the book too. Did you write the book in the order that we read it? In other words there are some alternating chapters past to present to past to present. Did you write it that way or did you write all the past and all the present and then cut them up? To tell you the truth I think I wrote alternating chapters. There were a couple of occasions when perhaps the episodes in the past I may have split them up and inserted a chapter from the present or from the near future but for the most part I actually did go back and forth. I did not write them in the order that they actually occur in the book however as a matter of fact the first thing in the book, the prologue, I wrote at the very end after I had completed the composition of the entire novel. I might also add here that David Hartwell, my editor at Timescape, was instrumental in helping me to cut down the book. It was considerably longer than it is now and it's quite a long novel anyway. He suggested the elimination of some chapters that were really kind of peripheral to the development of Joshua Kampa and also peripheral to the story of his return to and his life among the early hominids. So it would be difficult for me right now to reconstruct the exact order in which I wrote the individual chapters of that book but I did write some segments in the past, come and write some in the present and then eventually go back and kind of shuffle them together as if I were shuffling a deck of cards but perhaps and at least I hope so with a degree more not the same degree of randomness. I read, unfortunately I wasn't there but I read that in your nebula acceptance speech that you mentioned David Hartwell a couple of times and mentioned that he had been helpful so I take it that writers do appreciate it when good editors can come along and help them see the forest instead of the trees or the trees instead of the forest whatever you're supposed to say. Well I owe a special debt of gratitude to Hartwell. I would have to go back as far as a little knowledge for instance because he helped me with that book, he helped me with catacomb years and although he had moved over to Timescape which then was simply a pocketbook Simon and Schuster before he came up with the Timescape logo there but he helped me also with transfigurations in other words he was at Berkeley Putnam when that book was contracted for but he moved to pocketbooks before he had a chance to work on it. Nevertheless he did give me some help on it and he gave me a lot of help as I've indicated on no enemy but time. I don't know whether all writers appreciate that sort of editorial help and direction but I know that I can use it upon occasion and I think that Hartwell happens to be one of the people in the field who can give intelligent help. Under Heaven's Bridge was a collaboration with Ian Watson with whom you've collaborated on editing some short stories if I remember right since then. How did the mechanics of collaborating take place and I also wanted to venture a guess that the aliens were mostly you mostly your aliens. I just wanted to throw that in. Yeah the aliens really are my aliens because what he even wanted to do in fact what he suggested is that I write a story about the aliens the signosticoid from a little knowledge and catacomb years but rather than showing them in a human environment the urban nuclei that I take them and show them against their background of their home planet. So I told him I think I wrote him a letter we've been corresponding since about 1976 I believe and I wrote him a letter and said I'm really tired of those aliens I don't think I want to do anything else with them at all. I'm finished with them and he wrote back at that juncture and gave me a number of interesting ideas about them and said it's really too bad because there are lots of good things that we could still do with them and at that point we decided that maybe we could go ahead and collaborate on it. So the aliens were mine and he even wanted to see what they would be like on their own home world so we sent an expedition an earth expedition to their home planet and had them encounter those aliens there. We gave them a different name because we discovered a number of things about the star system 61's sickness is not really the kind of double binary that would support the kind of life that I had come up with in a little knowledge and catacomb years so we had to change a few things and so I think we called them kybers in Under Heaven's bridge which indicates that they are a kind of cyborg organism but naturally so that they evolved in that fashion and as far as the mechanics of the collaboration, Ian sent me about 30 pages of material which included a beginning, a middle and an end and suggested that we work from that as kind of an outline. I took those 30 pages and expanded them to about 100 and then we simply worked on in perpillating new chapters in that material. I believe Ian wrote the prologue to the book as well and I had final control over the entire manuscript just to make sure that the style was fairly consistent throughout. Kay, I want to get off now and ask a couple of questions about poetry and how it relates to your work. White Otters of Childhood which I said a while ago was my favorite story. The hero was Mark Cryer-Raines and he's a poet and he talks a lot about poetry in the story and he quotes poetry and he said there's a quote I remember one time where he said, you can't write poetry when your spirit is submerged. So I wanted to kind of delve into that. Is that you talking? Because you do write poetry and there must be some of you and him and is that true? Is that the way a poet works? Oh, golly. I think I probably ought to acknowledge a debt here to Roger Zalazny in particular. I don't know whether you know you must know. His early story arose from Ecclesiastes which has as its protagonist a poet and that story of his I believe, well it is, it's my favorite story of his and I think I was probably working with that story in mind when I wrote The White Otters of Childhood. I'll also have to say that I had read recently, by that I mean before I began writing The White Otters, I had read the poetry of St. John Perce who was a French poet, was a diplomat who also wrote poetry and he has a long poem called C-Marks and some of the lines in that particular poem suggested the title of The White Otters of Childhood to me and also the nature of the protagonist, also the nature of the mood that I tried to evoke in the story. I don't think anybody has really paid much attention to that or even noticed it even though I think I quote from him at the head of one of the sections of the story I use an epigraph of his at the head of one of the sections. As far as it being impossible to write poetry when the spirit is submerged, is that what I said? That's what you said. Okay, I would say that that's probably true. That disturbs me a little bit because I find that lately I've written less and less poetry. I'm not sure that my spirit is submerged so much as I am that poetry does not put food on the table whereas prose can sometimes do that. So I have written a lot more prose lately than I have poetry although I still like poetry and would like to be able to write more. What I need to do is ask you a short answer question and then flip my tape and I have two more after that. So I'll reverse the order because I wanted to ask the other one first. Is science fiction poetry viable because you have written some science fictional poetry as well. I have down here the rhyme between Betelgeuse and Proust and for the lady of a physicist I was kind of tickled by that rhyme. But science fiction poetry is just a gimmick that people can use and get into magazines. Do you think that's something that's real and maybe will become more important? Well I've always felt that it was possible to write poetry about anything so that it seems to me entirely possible and viable and legitimate to write poetry about speculative subjects or subjects that use science in one way or another. Whether it's a gimmick on the part of the people who are writing it to get into the magazines I have no idea. I'm sure that the science fiction magazines could not publish any other type of poetry however but poetry that deals with the speculative subject or with science in some way or another. Okay we need to flip our tape if you want to take a quick break and then we'll take a break.

segments.text: Now the tape is on, so everything is on.
I will tell you to be honest from the start
that I don't feel real suited
to do this interview. I really like your work. I've read everything. I've read some of it more than once.
I'm a real left hemisphere person
and so some of the things that you write I feel instead of
I don't see the logic, but I feel it. And so sometimes I'm going to be
grabbing for words because I just don't know how to express myself very well.
I'm better on tapers than a loud.
Well we edit this heavily and try to
make everybody sound as good as possible. It's very informal.
If you want us to repeat a question or you don't like something you said or something we said
we'll just go back and do it over with so there's no problem. And if you got to take a break or you just get tired
or whatever just let me know. So let's start it.
Okay your background is in English
and apparently you went quite far in your education in English and then
teaching and now you're a writer and you write science fiction.
How did you decide or why as a person so interested
in English do you write in the genre of science fiction?
Well the truth is that I have wanted
to be a writer since I was in about the eighth grade and I did not
necessarily want to be a science fiction writer. I wanted to be just a writer.
The reason that I am doing science fiction now
or have done primarily science fiction is that
I was first successful in submitting stories that had
a fantastic or a science fictional element and in having them
sell the other stories, the mainstream stories that I wrote
received primarily rejection slips early on
and as I said before
I'm kind of like the rat in the experimental
cage who goes to the lever and presses it and when the food
comes out of one particular lever that's the one he goes back to and continues
to press and that's the way I have done as far as
science fiction goes to some extent. It's not that I don't care for science fiction
and I'm doing it solely because it was profitable
or more profitable than the other type of writing
but simply that I ended up finding very
receptive editors in this particular field
and that accounts for it more or less.
Does science fiction give you perhaps a range
it's very forgiving as far as the subject matter and the way it's handled a little more
so than other genres. Is that attractive to you? Certainly I think that's
true. I think that science fiction does permit a writer to deal with just about
anything that he or she wishes to deal with.
You can handle contemporary events by
projecting them into the future. You can speculate about
the past. You can speculate about the distant, distant future. You can
speculate about origins and ultimate ends so that I think that really
science fiction is a tremendously flexible genre and that's one of its main
attractions to me and one of the reasons why I think I continue to write it even though
I have aspirations to do other things and have done other things.
Do you write for a particular audience
or do you write what pleases you and it
by happy chance does seem to tickle a lot of people?
I think that for the most part I try to write what interests me and I hope
then that it will interest somebody else. I've read a number of things
fairly recently which suggest that
even though my work is very well crafted
and carefully thought out that I may be
not reaching the audience that some other writers are reaching
because their work seems more readily accessible on a first look
I wish that that were not the case but I don't know how to do things any differently
than I do them. I try not to be inaccessible, that's for certain
and I do feel that some of my more recent work has reached a larger audience
than perhaps the first two or three novels that I wrote.
